activity.title: The Derivative of a Familiar Function

statement.p: Consider the function f whose formula is \displaystyle f(x) = 3 - 2x.

ol.label: a
ol.li: What familiar type of function is f? What can you say about the slope of f at every value of x?
Compute the average rate of change of f on the intervals [1,4], [3,7], and [5,5+h]; simplify each result as much as possible. What do you notice about these quantities?

Use the limit definition of the derivative to compute the exact instantaneous rate of change of f with respect to x at the value a = 1. That is, compute f'(1) using the limit definition. Show your work. Is your result surprising?
Without doing any additional computations, what are the values of f'(2), f'(\pi), and f'(-\sqrt{2})? Why?

ol.label: a
ol.li: If f(x) = 3x^2 + 2x - 4, we say f is quadratic. If f(x) = 5 e^{2x-1}, we say f is exponential. What do we say about f(x) = 3-2x?
Remember that to compute the average rate of change of f on [a,b], we calculate \frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}.
Think about the how the graph of f appears. What is the same at every point?

ol.label: a
ol.li: The average rate of change on [1,4], [3,7], and [5,5+h] is -2.
f'(2)=-2, f'(\pi)=-2, and f'(-\sqrt{2})=-2, since the slope of a linear function is the same at every point.

ol.label: a
ol.li: Because f(x) = 3 - 2x is of the form f(x) = mx + b, we call f a linear function.
